Articles.Content: I only just learned that Europa has one. Apparently it is VEEEERY thin, though.

Europa's atmosphere is just like the moon's; it essentially consists of charged particles from sunlight interactions from the crust. You certainly wouldn't use it for anything (whereas on say Mars, the atmosphere, however thin, can still be used for aerocapture; and even the 1/70,000 bar atmosphere of Triton will have an impact on precision landings)

Page 485 of this book has some more info: http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Jpcz2UoXejgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0816528446&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D0mjUdjUJpD30gX914CIAg&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false
Most bodies in our solar system have atmospheres; itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just that they are so thin itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hardly worth mentioning.
